Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Probe-Based Near Infrared Autofluorescence for Parathyroid Identification

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to either the probe-based NIRAF group or the control group.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial enrolled patients undergoing parathyroidectomy for primary hyperparathyroidism at a single institution.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to either the probe-based NIRAF group or the control group.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the benefits of probe-based near infrared autofluorescence (NIRAF) for parathyroid identification.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of parathyroids identified with high confidence by the surgeon and resident, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 160 patients were randomised, with 80 in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The senior surgeon's identification rate improved significantly in the probe group from 3.2 to 3.6 parathyroids per patient (p<0.001), and the junior surgeon's rate increased from 2.2 to 2.5 (p=0.001). Residents showed a significant increase from 0.9 to 2.9 parathyroids per patient (p<0.001).
